Article.Abstract: BACKGROUND: We investigated respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)-specific CD8(+) memory T cell responses in healthy control participants (n=31) and in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (n=9), with respect to frequency, memory phenotype, and proliferative requirements. METHODS: We investigated respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)-specific CD8(+) memory T cell responses in healthy control participants (n=31) and in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (n=9), with respect to frequency, memory phenotype, and proliferative requirements.The properties of RSV-specific CD8(+) T cells were analyzed by use of RSV tetramers. The proliferative requirements of RSV-specific CD8(+) T cells were analyzed by culture of peripheral-blood mononuclear cells with RSV peptide in combination with distinct cytokines. RESULTS: We investigated respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)-specific CD8(+) memory T cell responses in healthy control participants (n=31) and in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (n=9), with respect to frequency, memory phenotype, and proliferative requirements.The properties of RSV-specific CD8(+) T cells were analyzed by use of RSV tetramers. The proliferative requirements of RSV-specific CD8(+) T cells were analyzed by culture of peripheral-blood mononuclear cells with RSV peptide in combination with distinct cytokines.RSV-specific CD8(+) memory T cells showed a high level of expression of CD27 and interleukin-7R alpha and a low level of expression of CCR7. In the healthy participants, the frequency of RSV tetramer(+) CD8(+) T cells was significantly lower than the frequency of influenza virus A (FLU) tetramer(+) CD8(+) T cells (P=.0001). In contrast to FLU tetramer(+) CD8(+) T cells, we could detect RSV tetramer(+) CD8(+) T cells in the subgroup of elderly healthy participants (age, > or =55 years) and in the patients with COPD only after in vitro expansion. Expanded RSV-specific T cells produced interferon- gamma and granzyme B. CONCLUSION: We investigated respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)-specific CD8(+) memory T cell responses in healthy control participants (n=31) and in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (n=9), with respect to frequency, memory phenotype, and proliferative requirements.The properties of RSV-specific CD8(+) T cells were analyzed by use of RSV tetramers. The proliferative requirements of RSV-specific CD8(+) T cells were analyzed by culture of peripheral-blood mononuclear cells with RSV peptide in combination with distinct cytokines.RSV-specific CD8(+) memory T cells showed a high level of expression of CD27 and interleukin-7R alpha and a low level of expression of CCR7. In the healthy participants, the frequency of RSV tetramer(+) CD8(+) T cells was significantly lower than the frequency of influenza virus A (FLU) tetramer(+) CD8(+) T cells (P=.0001). In contrast to FLU tetramer(+) CD8(+) T cells, we could detect RSV tetramer(+) CD8(+) T cells in the subgroup of elderly healthy participants (age, > or =55 years) and in the patients with COPD only after in vitro expansion. Expanded RSV-specific T cells produced interferon- gamma and granzyme B.We provide evidence that a pool of functional RSV-specific CD8(+) memory T cells persists in the peripheral blood of healthy individuals and patients with COPD. Low numbers of RSV-specific memory T cells in the elderly and in patients with COPD may explain the increased susceptibility to RSV infection in these populations.
Article.ArticleTitle: Respiratory syncytial virus-specific CD8+ memory T cell responses in elderly persons.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Pulmonology, Academic Medical Center, University of Amsterdam, 1100 DE Amsterdam, The Netherlands. g.j.debree@amc.uva.nl.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMC were stimulated with IL-2 and the epitope for 7 days prior to the assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Proliferation of tetramer + CD8+ T cells was observed by CFSE in PBMC from healthy donors after culture with IL-2 and epitope. This proliferation could be blocked by anti-IL-2Ra antibody. Down-regulation of IL-7Ra was also demonstrated. Incubation of PBMC with the epitope and either IL-7 or IL-15 also induced proliferation of epitope-specific CD8+ T cells while the use of IL-21did not. PBMC were stimulated with IL-2 and the epitope for 7 days prior to the assay.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMC were stimulated with the epitope alone or with the epitope and RSV antigen for 7 days prior to the assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Proliferation of tetramer + CD8+ T cells was not observed by CFSE in PBMC from healthy donors after culture with the epitope with or without additional RSV antigen. PBMC were stimulated with the epitope alone or with the epitope and RSV antigen for 7 days prior to the assay.

The frequency of tetramer positive CD8+ T cells was found to decrease as the age of the donor increased and was significantly lower than the frequency of influenza NP 44-52 and M1 58-66 specific CD8+ T cells in healthy donors. CD8+ tetramer positive cells were of the resting memory phenotype expressing high levels of CD27, CD28 and IL-7Ra, a low level of CCR7, and no HLA-DR or CD38. CD8+ tetramer + cells proliferated in response to culture with the epitope and IL-2 for 7 days.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMC were stimulated with IL-2 and the epitope for 7 days prior to tetramer assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Tetramer + CD8+ T cells were observed in healthy donors after culture with IL-2 and epitope. These cells proliferated (by CFSE) and down-regulated IL-7Ra. PBMC were stimulated with IL-2 and the epitope for 7 days prior to tetramer assay.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: CD8+ tetramer positive cells were sorted and cultured for 4 weeks in the presence of EBV-transformed B cells presenting the epitope and IL-2 prior to tetramer assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CD8+ tetramer positive cells were of the memory phenotype, expressing a high level of granzyme B after 4 weeks of culture with the epitope. CD8+ tetramer positive cells were sorted and cultured for 4 weeks in the presence of EBV-transformed B cells presenting the epitope and IL-2 prior to tetramer assay.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMC from COPD patients were stimulated with IL-2 and the epitope for 7 days prior to tetramer assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CD8+ T cells from Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) patients bound tetramers presenting the epitope only after 7 days of culture with the epitope and IL-2.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMC from COPD patients were stimulated with IL-2 and the epitope for 7 days prior to tetramer assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CD8+ T cells from Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) patients bound tetramers presenting the epitope only after 7 days of culture with the epitope and IL-2.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMC were stimulated with IL-2 and the epitope for 7 days prior to tetramer assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Tetramer + CD8+ T cells were measured in healthy donors after culture with IL-2 and epitope for 7 days. Proliferation was also observed by CFSE. PBMC were stimulated with IL-2 and the epitope for 7 days prior to tetramer assay.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMC were from COPD patients immunized with the influenza vaccine 4-6 months prior to the study. PBMC were stimulated with IL-2 and the epitope for 7 days prior to tetramer assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Tetramer + CD8+ T cells from Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) patients bound tetramers presenting the epitope and were observed to proliferate by CFSE staining. PBMC were stimulated with IL-2 and the epitope for 7 days prior to tetramer assay.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: All donors were immunized with the influenza vaccine 4-6 months prior to the study. PBMC were stimulated with IL-2 and the epitope for 7 days prior to tetramer assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Tetramer + CD8+ T cells were measured in healthy donors after culture with IL-2 and epitope. Proliferation was observed by CFSE. PBMC were stimulated with IL-2 and the epitope for 7 days prior to tetramer assay.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: All donors were immunized with the influenza vaccine 4-6 months prior to the study.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The frequency of tetramer positive CD8+ T cells was found to be significantly higher than the frequency of RSV M 229-237 and NL9 specific CD8+ T cells in healthy donors. CD8+ tetramer positive cells were of the resting memory phenotype expressing high levels of CD27, CD28 and IL-7Ra, a moderate level of CCR7, and no HLA-DR or CD38.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Tetramer + CD8+ T cells were measured in healthy donors after culture with IL-2 and the epitope. Proliferation was observed by CFSE. PBMC were stimulated with IL-2 and the epitope for 7 days prior to tetramer assay.
